title-group.article-title: Cohesive zone modeling of coupled buckling – Debond growth in metallic honeycomb sandwich structure

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering, Trivandrum, India
2Honeycomb Product Development Division, SDEG Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, ISRO, Trivandrum, India

author-notes.corresp: KC Gopalakrishnan, Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering, Trivandrum 695016, India. Email: gopankcg@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Buckling-induced skin–core debond growth in honeycomb sandwich cantilever beam is demonstrated using a cohesive zone model. The input parameters for the analysis are interfacial bond strength, mode I and mode II interfacial fracture toughness values, obtained from flatwise tension tests, drum-peel tests and three-point end notch flexure tests, respectively. Debonded honeycomb specimens are tested and the acoustic emission technique was used to observe the initiation of the debond growth. The load-displacement response from the cohesive zone model model shows a good agreement with the experimental results. The conventional analysis without cohesive zone model overestimates failure load by 56%. Cohesive zone model is able to predict the coupled debond growth and buckling failure in honeycomb sandwich structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Metallic sandwich structures are widely used in the aerospace vehicles as primary and secondary load-bearing members such as pay-load fairing, payload adaptor, equipment bay due to their high bending stiffness at light weight. The interface bond between the face-sheets and the honeycomb core is necessary for the overall integrity of the sandwich structure to perform its task. A region, where there is no bond, is called debond and in this region, the face-sheet will lose its support from the core, which results in the loss of I-beam effect of the sandwich panel [1]. Sandwich structures often encounter debond problems due to in-service loading conditions, impact of foreign objects or high stress concentrations in the vicinity of geometric and material discontinuities [2]. Debonding leads to the reduction in the strength of the structure. In comparison to an undamaged sandwich structure, 87% reduction in load-carrying capacity was observed for a 25 mm through-width debonded structures reported by Aitken [3]. The behavior of debonded sandwich structure is much more complex and the ability to predict the damage tolerance is one of the key factors in the design of sandwich structures.

It has been demonstrated analytically and experimentally that debond growth does not occur until the debond region has buckled because growth is dominated by Mode I (peel) fracture [4–6]. Whitcomb [7] found that the peel stresses induced after buckling are the primary mechanism driving debond growth. The reduced buckling load due to the debond growth may be viewed as an endurance limit.

Interface debonding is generally very complex in nature and difficult to solve, because it involves not only geometric and material discontinuities but also oscillatory singularity nature of the stress and displacement field in the vicinity of the debond tip [8–10]. The method of defining an initial crack and assuming self-similar progression of it as in the traditional fracture mechanics approach becomes inefficient for modeling interface debonding [11,12]. To circumvent the difficulties by unifying strength-based crack initiation and fracture-based crack progression, the cohesive crack modeling approach has distinct advantages compared to other global methods [13,14]. It can be realized by the use of special interfacial de-cohesion elements, placed between material layers or in the structure where cracking can occur [15]. These elements introduce fracture mechanism by adopting softening relationships between tractions and the separations, which in turn introduce a critical fracture energy required to break apart the interface surfaces by combining a stress-based and fracture mechanics based formulation. These elements are surface-like and are compatible with finite element models of the structure [16].

The aim of the present study is to analyze, experimentally and numerically, the failure process of a debonded honeycomb sandwich cantilever beam due to combined buckling and debond growth, and capture the failure load associated with the process. In order to simulate numerically, nonlinear finite element analysis using 3D cohesive zone modeling (CZM) is performed. The interface between the core and skin is modeled using cohesive zone elements after experimentally obtaining the required parameters such as interfacial bond strength, mode-I fracture toughness and mode-II fracture toughness [17]. The load–displacement response of the beam is compared with the experimental results.

sec.title: Buckling-driven debond growth
sec.p:
In debonded sandwich cantilever beams carrying transverse load, local buckling causes the debond growth (Figure 1). An increase of debond size reduces the load-carrying capacity and, as both effects reinforce each other, failure must occur suddenly [18,19]. A large amount of research has been performed on this subject [20,21]. Kardomateas [22] studied the buckling and initial postbuckling behavior of facesheet debond or facesheet/core debonds based on nonlinear beam theory wit transverse shear deformation. Somers et al. [23], Kim and Figure 1.
Buckling-driven debond. Dharan [24] and Hwu and Hu [25] derived closed-form solutions of the critical buckling load. Chen et al. [26] presented a progressive analysis for various debond lengths to predict the local debond buckling load of sandwich beams. Most of these previous analyses decouple the interaction between structural behavior and the fracture process, and thus can be used as a first-order approximation for damage tolerance assessment [27]. One way to couple the structural behavior and the fracture process is to use a cohesive zone model. The model was introduced to investigate the fracture process with nonlinear fracture mechanics.

sec.title: Cohesive zone modeling
sec.p: The CZM is a damage mechanics model that describes the material behavior in the process zone ahead of a crack or debond and was first envisaged by Needleman [13,14]. Basically it uses a traction-separation (T-δ) relation which correlates the stress (opening traction) and the displacement jump (crack face opening) in the process zone [28,29]. The idea of a cohesive model is based on the consideration that infinite stresses at the crack tip are not realistic. CZM enables calculation of load for crack initiation and crack growth of ductile as well as brittle materials. The Dudgale–Barenblatt cohesive zone approach [12,30] served the theory for the decohesion elements used in finite element model (FEM). These elements use failure criteria that combine aspects of strength-based analysis to predict the onset of the softening process at the interface and fracture mechanics to predict debond propagation. An important advantage of decohesion elements is their capability to predict both onset and propagation of debond.

In interface debonding and failure simulation, the structure on either sides of the bond is modeled as two separate regions and discretized such that the nodes in the interface have same coordinate values, but with different node numbers. A layer of decohesion elements of zero thickness is introduced in between the regions [28,31]. The cohesive zone represents a narrow band of localized deformation and is idealized as a pair of surfaces on which cohesive traction acts. The load–displacement response of the cohesive zone is idealized by a traction-separation law.

sec.title: Exponential traction separation law
sec.p: According to Tvergaard and Hutchinson [31], debond growth is associated with tractions across the interface that reaches a maximum value corresponding to the onset of debond growth and then decreases gradually and finally vanishes when complete decohesion occurs [32,33]. The cohesive zone can still transfer load after the onset of debond, until the critical value of the energy release rate is attained. In the present study, this gradual decrease is represented as an exponential traction separation [34].

The exponential form of a cohesive zone model [13,14,35] uses a surface potential φ(δ) as (1)φ(δ)=exp(1)σmaxδn-[1-(1+Δn)exp(-Δn)·exp(-Δt2)] where, (2)Δn=δnδn- (3)Δt=δtδt- δn, δt and δ¯n, δ¯t are the nodal separations (of cohesive zone elements) and their peak values corresponding to opening and shear modes respectively. σmax is the normal strength at the interface and is obtained from flatwise tension (FWT) tests (Figure 2). τmax is the maximum shear strength of the adhesive bond between the skin and core, obtained from lap shear tests, is same as that of normal strength. Figure 2.
End notch flexure testing for evaluation of mode II fracture toughness. value GIIc = 2800 J/m2.

The normal and tangential traction forces Tn and Tt can be obtained by differentiating equation (1) with respect to δn and δt and are given as (4)Tn=exp(1)σmaxΔnexp(-Δn)·exp(-Δt2) (5)Tt=2exp(1)σmaxδn-δt-Δt(1+Δn)exp(-Δn)·exp(-Δt2) (6)φn=exp(1)σmaxδn- For pure mode I, the normal work of separation, φn or GIc is obtained by using equation (1) and specifying mode II displacements to zero. (7)φt=2exp(1)τmaxδt-
For pure mode II, the shear work of separation, φt or GIIc is obtained by using equation (1) and specifying mode I displacements to zero.

sec.title: Specimen properties
sec.p:
The buckling induced debond growth was investigated using a debonded honeycomb panel of size 635 × 100 × 41.6 mm3 and composed of aluminium skin (AA 2014 T6) of 0.8 mm thick bonded to aluminium core (AA 5056) of 40 mm height with 6 mm hexagonal cells. The skin and core are bonded together by epoxy based adhesive film except the debonded region of 75 mm as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Debonded specimen.

sec.title: Experimental methodology
sec.p:
Honeycomb core is bonded to chemically cleaned aluminium face sheets of 0.8 mm thickness using thin film adhesive (at 0.1 mm after curing) and cured following the well-known vacuum bag technique with negative pressure of one bar. Initial debond was provided by Teflon sheet placed at the interface between the core and face sheet. Trimmed and sized specimens (Table 1, Figure 3) are tested to ensure intact bond between core and skin by NDT (Fokker bond tester). Specimens are made in three sets. Table 1.
Properties of the specimen
Material properties
Thickness of the core foil – 0.0508 mm Density of the core – 66 kg/m3 Modulus of core foil (AA 5036) – 70 GPa Core modulus Ez – 1.7 GPa Shear moduli GLZ – 460 MPa GWZ – 180 MPa Modulus of the skin (AA 2014) – 70 GPa
First a specimen without debond is tested to calibrate the FEM wherein equivalent core properties are considered for comparison of load–deflection variation.

Second specimen with debond is tested by providing initial debond as shown in Figures 3 and 4. Then, to fine tune the load close to the failure and to capture the load at which the debond growth occurs (by acoustic emission (AE)) and to verify the consistency within the test data, a third specimen is tested up to failure. During loading of the specimen, AE is recorded to verify the debond growth. Details are given in the results and discussion section. Figure 4.
Experimental set-up for cantilever honeycomb sandwich beam with initial debond instrumented with AE sensors and dial gauges. AE: acoustic emission.

To evaluate the input parameters required for the numerical modeling by CZM, flatwise tension test (Figure 5) was done as per ASTM Standard C 297-94 to obtain interfacial bond strength of the adhesive, drum peel test was done as per ASTM standard D1781 to obtain mode I fracture toughness value and ENF test (Figure 2) was done to obtain mode II fracture toughness value [12,29]. Figure 5.
Cohesive mode of failure of FWT specimen (average value of interfacial strength σmax = 6.3 MPa). FWT: flatwise tension.

sec.title: Finite element analysis (CZM)
sec.p: In the 3D CZM model (using commercial software package ANSYS.11), the honeycomb core is modeled as homogenized core and its Young’s modulus in the thickness direction is obtained from the density ratio of honeycomb core and aluminium (Table 1).

The core and skin are meshed by using brick elements (Figure 6). Cohesive zone or the interface between the core and skin is modeled using eight-node zero thickness elements (inter 205), except in the debonded region of 75 mm as shown in Figure 3. Contact is defined between the skin and core, using conta-174 and targe-170 elements, to avoid the inter penetration of the two. One end of the beam is constrained for all degrees of freedom over a beam length of 30 mm while the opposite end is loaded (25 mm away from the tip as shown in Figure 3) by specifying displacements through inhomogeneous geometric boundary conditions. Figure 6.
Acoustic emission data monitoring.

A geometric nonlinear finite element analysis is carried out and the load displacement character of the beam is obtained to assess the effect of debond growth on the residual strength. The analysis is also repeated without considering the CZM approach to study the critical load-carrying capacity of the beam, due to buckling alone, in the absence of debond growth.

Following are the input required for the analysis:
Mode I debond fracture toughness, GIc – 930 J/m2 (based on the average value of drum peel test data for three specimens as per the ASTM standard D1781)
Mode II interfacial fracture toughness, GIIc – 2802 J/m2 (based on ENF tests of honeycomb specimen, Figure 2)
Interfacial normal tensile strength, σmax – 6.3 MPa ± 3% (Figure 5)
Interfacial shear strength, τmax – 6.3 MPa (same as normal strength)

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Initially, to validate the 3D FEM using the homogenized core, displacements obtained for a no-debond sandwich cantilever beam with a tip load of 300 N were compared with test. AE was monitored to observe the core crushing. A few AE signals were noticed at around 250 N and the test was stopped. Then for the subsequent specimens, the core was rigidized over 25 mm in the clamped end by drilling two pilot holes, injecting resin and curing at room temperature for 24 h, and tested up to 300 N. No AE signals were observed. Then the debonded specimens were loaded until failure and the load–displacement curve observed. A sudden failure was experienced after reaching a maximum load of 190 N and the post failure observation of the specimen shows buckling failure followed by debond growth (Figures 6 and 7). Figure 7.
Inelastic buckling failure and deformed configuration based on CZM analysis of metallic sandwich beam under bending. CZM: cohesive zone model.

sec.title: Test results
sec.p:
From the experimental study on aluminium skinned honeycomb sandwich beam with 75 mm debond (Figure 3), it is observed that at 190 N there is sudden failure of the sandwich beam with inelastic buckling of the skin under compression side (Figures 7 and 8). During loading of the specimen, AE was monitored to detect onset of debond growth. Up to 170 N (around 970 s, Figure 6), only few AE signals were registered. Post test data could reveal that those few signals were due to the noise generated while applying load. No AE signal was registered during the hold phases. During the load-holding phase at around 180 N (980 s), three low amplitude AE signals were registered which indicated the presence of some minor activity. At 190 N (995 s), a flood of higher amplitude AE signals were registered indicating the debond growth and the specimen failed suddenly. Post test observation showed a debond growth of 4 mm on either side. Table 2.
Load-displacement data
Test
Load (N) 0 27 55 80 106 157 174 178 182 184 185 188 190 Sudden Failure
Deflection (mm) 0 2.5 5 7.5 10 17 22 25 28 32 36 40 45
CZM
Load (N) 13 26 45 73 110 149 165 170 172 175 180 185 186 188
Deflection (mm) 1 2 3 5 9 14 19 20 22 30 35 40 45 51
Non-linear buckling (No Cohesive Zone)
Load (N) 0 26 45 72 110 149 167 175 186 198 213 253 275 297
Deflection (mm) 0 2 34 5 10 14 19 25 35 51 71 132 160 182
Figure 8.
Load–displacement response at the load point.

sec.title: Comparison between the test and analysis results
sec.p:
Nonlinear finite element analysis after interface modeling by CZM gives a peak failure load of 188 N (Table 2, Table 3) and shows debond growth on either side and ultimate failure at lower load of 163 N (Figure 8). Comparison of the test data shows an agreement on the peak load with analysis. Nonlinear finite element analysis without introducing CZM is also carried out on the debonded specimen and the result indicates peak failure load of 297 N (Table 2, Figure 8). A deviation of 56% in nonlinear buckling analysis and 1.05% in CZM model with experimental results are observed for the peak load. Table 3.
Comparison of failure loads by test and analysis
Failure load (N) Test (average of two) Buckling analysis without CZM CZM
Peak load (N) 190 297 188
Variation with experimental result (peak value) (%) – 56 1.05

Based on the present study on a CZM model, the parameters required for the failure are interfacial bond strength and interfacial fracture toughness and these parameters decide whether the failure, of a debonded structure under bending, is due to buckling alone without any debond growth or buckling-induced debond growth followed by buckling failure.

sec.title: Parametric study of the inputs for CZM on the peak load
sec.p: A parametric study was carried out to evaluate the effect of interfacial strength, mode I fracture toughness and mode II fracture toughness values on the peak load-carrying capacity of the debonded sandwich beam after varying any one of the values and keeping the other values constant.

sec.title: Keeping fracture toughness values constant
sec.p:
Interfacial bond strength values were varied from 1 to 10 MPa while keeping the fracture toughness values constant (GIc = 930 J/m2 and GIIc = 2802 J/m2) and observed that the peak load of the sandwich beam with debond increases with the increase in interfacial strength linearly beyond FWT value greater than 2 MPa (Figure 9). Figure 9.
Effect of interfacial strength on peak load.

sec.title: Keeping interfacial bond strength constant
sec.p:
It is interesting to note that effect of mode I debond fracture toughness on the peak load is very significant than mode II. The study was carried out for a range of mode I fracture toughness values from 1 to 3200 J/m2 (Figure 10). For very low values of mode I fracture toughness from 1 to 200 J/m2, there was a large increase in failure load from 6 to 168 N and thereafter the increase is 168 to 208 N. However, for the same range of mode II fracture toughness values, no significant effect on peak load was observed. For the mode II fracture toughness values from 1 to 10 J/m2, the peak load was from 169 to 194 N but further increase in fracture toughness value was not made any difference in peak load of 193 N. In other words, mode II fracture toughness does not play a key role in deciding the peak load. This study reveals that coupled buckling induced debond growth is a mode I dominated property and the failure load of the beam is controlled by mode I fracture toughness and interfacial strength values. Figure 10.
Effect of fracture toughness on peak load.

Figure 11 shows the debond tip opening on both the sides of the initial debond provided on the specimen. During initial stages of the loading up to 160 N, mode II shear opening dominates over mode I normal opening and thereafter the mode I opening dominates and lead to failure of the specimen. This was due to the compressive strain at the bottom skin. As the skin buckling progresses, there was reduction in compressive stress and strain, which caused the decrease in shear opening and increase in normal opening. Figure 11.
Variation of debond tip opening based on CZM approach. CZM: cohesive zone model.
This study reveals that the maximum shear opening was 25% of the maximum normal opening (Figure 11) and the ultimate failure was governed by mode I opening and mode I fracture toughness value.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Metallic honeycomb sandwich cantilever beams with debond have been tested and coupled buckling and debond growth failure observed. Experiments were performed to measure the parameters of cohesive zone model. Interfacial normal strength (σmax), GIc and GIIc values were measured from FWT tests, climbing drum peel tests and ENF tests, respectively. Numerical simulation of the test was done by a CZM approach to evaluate the coupled debond growth and buckling on peak failure load of the beam. Comparison of the simulated and measured load–displacement response shows a very good agreement. It is observed that the skin buckling causes debond growth and subsequent buckling failure. Both the test and analysis show same mode of failure of skin buckling accompanied by debond growth. Parametric study revealed that buckling induced debond growth and subsequent failure of sandwich beams are a mode I dominated property and the critical parameters defines the failure are interfacial normal strength and mode I fracture toughness values of the adhesive.

A homogenized core model with cohesive zone element introduced at the interface between the skin and the honeycomb core can be successfully used to capture the coupled buckling induced debond growth and predict the failure load of the sandwich structures.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
